question: List all the different temperatures that a user has cooked onions. List them with date, temp, and outcome if available.

events.method: in a pan with water and oil

evidence.excerpt: putting some onions in a pan then adding water and oil

events.outcome: Adding ~2 tbsp butter and water reportedly helped slow burning and more evenly distributed heat

evidence.excerpt: i’ve added some keri gold butter and water probably about 2 tablespoons on the first round and then I just did it again ... I think it helped slow some of the burning and more evenly distributed some of the heat temperatures are still around 229° when I checked it and it could’ve been that way for up to a half an hour around then

events.method: water bath (jar in water bath)
events.outcome: Used as part of a sweet hollandaise sauce (jar heated with caramelized onions and egg yolks)

evidence.excerpt: making a sweet hollandaise sauce. The first video is me putting the caramelized onions and egg yolks for a little bit of honey in a jar. And then the second video was me putting that jar in a water bath at 140 something degrees at 141°

events.method: sous vide circulator (4–5 hours)
events.outcome: Caramelized onion prepared; jar refrigerated overnight

evidence.excerpt: I had I put the jar of egg and sous vide egg yolk and caramelized onion in the refrigerator overnight. This had been in a sous vide circulator at about 140.5° for maybe 4 to 5 hours.

events.method: sous vide bath (reheating)
events.outcome: Reheating after refrigeration (warming); outcome not further described

evidence.excerpt: A refrigerated overnight and I’m reheating it in a sous vide bath at around 105° because I was already making some yogurt

events.method: cooking with the lid on
events.outcome: not translucent

evidence.excerpt: checking the temperature of the onions after the after they’ve been cooking with the lid on. There’s some steam and a little bit of sizzling but not quite translucent at all

events.method: cooking (lid removed)
events.outcome: starting to become a little translucent; shrunk slightly

evidence.excerpt: cooking at about 182 degrees onions are starting to become a little translucent and I think they have shrunk just a little bit. I removed the pot lid

events.outcome: Onions became much more brown while cooking at this temperature.

evidence.excerpt: The onions have become much more brown at times they were cooking at about 210°

events.outcome: Heat was turned down and the onions cooked at an average of ~180° (continued browning after lowering heat).

evidence.excerpt: but then I turned the heat down on average it’s been around 180°

events.method: pan on stovetop (low, dial ~2)

evidence.excerpt: it was on low and I think it was maybe around 165°

events.method: pan on stovetop (heat turned up from ~2 to ~4)
events.outcome: some pieces significantly browned; some larger pieces still translucent and not very brown

evidence.excerpt: it started to go up to like 270 or somewhere in the 270° range and as you can see there’s significant browning in some of the pieces and still translucent

events.method: mixed into omelette (contrast with used as a topping)
events.outcome: Mixing the onion into the omelette mutes its punch; notes on sweetness, onion flavor, and dilution effect

evidence.excerpt: Thanks for sharing your thoughts on the sweetness, onion flavor, and dilution effect in the omelette. I hear you on how mixing it in mutes the punch compared to using it as a topping. I'm here if you want help tweaking it next time!

events.method: roasting; sauce reduction
events.outcome: crispy-skinned; sauce reduced; roasted flavor

evidence.excerpt: Glad to hear the crispy-skinned one shined after the sauce reduction. That roasted flavor sounds lovely. Thanks for the update.

events.method: pan — scooped warmed sous-vide onion-egg mixture into eggs on the pan
events.outcome: Eggs were cooked a little; mixture was scooped in and later incorporated/stirred.

evidence.excerpt: I scooped ... after they were cooked a little bit that around and 130° range ...

events.method: pan — scooped warmed sous-vide onion-egg mixture into eggs on the pan
events.outcome: Pan was a little hot; mixture was added while eggs were partially cooked and incorporated/stirred.

evidence.excerpt: around and 130° range and 140° range of a pan was a little bit hot

events.method: pan — brief temperature spike of the pan while incorporating the mixture
events.outcome: User removed pan from heat when it briefly reached ~150°F, then continued incorporating/stirring the mixture.

evidence.excerpt: it briefly got up to what I tested it about 150° so I took it off the heat and then incorporating and stirred more of the mixture in

events.method: sous-vide
events.outcome: At ~4 hours the taste was okay but the mix was grainy/coarse; by ~10 hours the onion flavor was much improved.

evidence.excerpt: assistant (msg 44): "Noted: egg blended with caramelized onions, sous-vide at 145° for about 4 hours." user (msg 45): "after about 4 hours, the taste was ok and the mix was grainy or course. Tasted it again after about 10 and it the onion taste was much improved. the extra hours significantly improved the flavor of the egg caramelized onion mix"

events.method: briefly raised surface temperature of the pan
events.outcome: Gave nice color and doneness

events.method: caramelization (cooked for about another hour)
events.outcome: Avocado oil boosted the onion's sweetness; overall results described as tasty; salmon + egg mix produced distinct but complementary flavors rather than a single blended flavor.

evidence.excerpt: I cooked the caramelized onions ... I cooked all three for about another hour and 142.5°. Adding the avocado oil really brought out the sweetness in the onion.

events.method: sous vide
events.outcome: Eggs blended with caramelized onions (caramelized onions present); cooked sous vide for about 4 hours

events.method: caramelized (prior preparation; method unspecified)

events.method: Diced onions cooked in a small pan with ~2 tablespoons butter on stovetop; user tried to keep pan at ~250° for about 20 minutes; foamed heavily and browned (like frying) but did not burn; mixture was strained.

evidence.excerpt: tasting the air as onions met butter

events.method: pan
events.outcome: After ~30 minutes: starting to get more translucent with noticeable browning on some smaller parts.

evidence.excerpt: This is a picture of the onions think now it's been I don't know maybe 30 minutes they're starting to get more translucent noticeable some browning and some of the smaller parts and the temperature is about 185° on the pan

events.method: pan around this temperature (~30 minutes in)
events.outcome: After ~30 minutes onions more translucent with some browning on smaller pieces.

evidence.excerpt: about 30 minutes in, onions are more translucent with some browning on smaller pieces; pan around 185°F.

events.method: softened for about an hour at low temperature
events.outcome: Softened (slow-cooked) over ~1 hour.

evidence.excerpt: softened for about an hour at low temperature around 180 degrees

events.method: temperature increased to searing/high heat for ~15 minutes
events.outcome: Crunchy with spots of brown around edges or small pieces; larger pieces translucent white; maintained texture crunch with some browning flavor.

evidence.excerpt: kicked up to around 300 degrees for about 15 minutes. Crunchy and spots of brown around edges or small pieces with larger ones translucent white.
